I love this bakery. They are making my wedding cake- strawberry shortcake with natural marzipan to cover.
The cake tasting was a bit confusing at first- you must narrow your choices to three cakes to taste from all of the options they have. They have a brochure- then they make them up for you to taste. It is fantastic. And Vittoria who helped us is great, she is a tough lady with a twinkle in her eye. We wanted to buy a cake, she made it happen no fuss no muss.
author: SuperRockStar N.

description: I went here to try out their coconut macaroons, tiramisu cake, some pine nut cookies, and it was simply heaven. The tiramisu cake was absolutely to die for. I never ate a tiramisu cake as good as this one. It is quite expensive, but the size of slice of cake you get, it's worth it. Apparently their coconut macaroons are their best selling pastry, I went here to get it, but unfortunately they ran out, but they sent me to their sister store to get some. I was lucky to get the last one! YAY... I totally recommend this place if you want some really good deserts. They go buy weight, so it can add up if you buy a lot of their pastries.
author: Carmen A.

description: Am I ordering the wrong things?  All I got were mediocre cakes for an insane price.
author: Tiffany H.

description: I pretty much bought half of the bakery when I came. I had some brownies, cannolis, amaretti cookies, italian rum cake, and princess cake. Everything was great! I'm a huge princess cake fan and the marzipan was so thick and yummy. The cake itself was a litle dry but I think that If I had a fresh cake made for me, it would be perfection. The cannolis were very yummy, as were the cookies, brownies, and other cake. I wouldn't necessarily say that this is the best bakery, but they do have great stuff :)
author: Sheeva G.

description:
This place has been here for ages and finally one day my lady and I decided to step in.

We werent really sure what to get, she was craving for a tiramisu and I was hankering for a blueberry muffin. Both were very good and I'm quite sure I will be back when I'm in the area. The carrot cake looked delicious.

Service was good~
author: phillip w.

description:
Been coming here since I was a baby, my grandpa often made a stop here whenever we were in the area.  Best pastry - Princess Cake!!  
The service is always friendly.  It's cute to see a group of BFF Nonnas gather here from time to time as regulars. 
Anyway, really good princess cake.  That's all I gotta say.
author: Marzan W.

description:
Their Saint Honore cake is amazing.  That's all I really have had here since my dad loves it.  All I know is that there is some Bavarian cream and rum in it and it involves cream puffs, custard and vanilla.  

And I have never ever not loved it.  

Here is a definition of it if you want to see what it is:  

http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-st-honore-cake.htm

Or just go to the bakery and order one!
author: Denise B.

description:
Used to go here in the 1980s...and the old Italian ladies were so friendly and funny.  The people there are still nice but I think I'm not used to the flavors anymore.  Still, if you're craving some desserts while walking in the neighborhood, this isn't a bad choice.  It's really in Chinatown, though yelp lists them as being in No. Beach.  I guess the border is around this corner (Vallejo and Stockton). 

Nice that they're still around.
author: Ye W.

description: Everyone should run here and buy everything right now! They have the best pastries of SF has to offer. Forget about the rest! Open since 1914 this year they're celebrating it with free give aways. Not sure when yet but I sure hope I can get a jump on it. So drop what yuo're doing and get here this minute. Employees needs a job and you will contribute to it.
author: James K.

description:
On my way to Chinatown and needed something HOT to warm me up from today's blustery SF wind. This place was across the street from where I had parked so it just seemed logical to come here first since I knew I wouldn't find a decent cup of joe in Chinatown.

The place looked like a regular pastry shop. Glancing at the menu pastries ranged from ($3.95 to $4.50) Tiramisu, Napoleon, cream puffs, eclairs, tarts, truffles, cannoli and danishes, the latter sweet option priced from $1.85 to $2.45. They also had cookies and cakes in all sorts of flavors and prices.

But I wasn't here for the pastries...which is probably why my experience here wasn't too favorable. I came in and ordered a small vanilla latte ($2.90) which turned out to be luke warm and way too sweet. I know the syrups are sweet, but even Starbucks doesn't cause me to try and find some water to hydrate myself.

The place looked popular to locals for it offered several small tables and people were popping in and out of the place. I guess you come here for the treats and not the coffee. My bad.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I always tend to come here for their St Honore cake. It's probably the best in the city. You can't get anything better then the whipped cream cake rimmed with miniature custard fill cream puffs. Inside has layers of Italian leaf pastry, custard, and rum soaked cake. Each bite you take is a sweet bite.

Remember to savor the custard fill cream puffs cuz those ROCK!
author: Juliane N.

description: Decent.   Nothing blowing me away at the moment...   I would not go out of my way for this spot,  but would return if the moment was right.  If your nearby and want some cake or a sugar rush, then have at it.  So many other spots in the city to try though.  Its seems to have a history and a following that doesn't come overnight and that says something to me.  Stop in and get some saturated fat and take a stroll to burn it off while smelling the sometimes odd scents of the city.
author: Duke B.

description: actually discovered Princess Cake from VPC at a cafe in Sausalito -- loved the cake so much that I inquired its origin.  "We get the desserts delivered from Victoria Pastry in San Fran."  So back in 2013 had to go to the source in North Beach.  I know it's been discussed before, but their Princess Cake is divine.   Pastry cream, whipped cream, and marzipan with one layer of raspberry jam is perfection.   Their tiramisu is a little heavy on the alcohol, but still good.  The other pastries I've tried have been good, but don't knock your socks off like the Princess Cake.   So on our last day driving out to Redwood City to our son's house, we were going to pick up Princess Cake but Richmond bakery called Schubert's was way more convenient.  VPC is a slightly better cake but about 60% more expensive than Schubert's on Clement St., so take that into account if you don't want the hassle of North Beach and want to pay $20 for a cake rather than $34.   Wish I got to the Bay area more often (only there about once/year to visit my son & his gf) as I adore VPC.   The owner & the staff are sweeties.  A few tables out front in the shade, as well as a few tables inside where my long-suffering husband sits & waits (he rarely eats desserts).  Miss you already as the DC area where I live has a dearth of good Italian pastry.   North End in Boston & North Beach in San Fran are the best IMAO if you're into cannolis, tiramisu, that zabaione cake (sfaggonia, one of my other favorites when I don't choose the Princess Cake).
author: Suzanne G.

description: As my 5 year anniversary passes and my wife and I reflect on our beautiful wedding at Sts Peter and Pail, we can't help but remember what a horrific job Victoria pastry did with our $1000 cake. I believe the above post, short and to the point, reflects our dissatisfaction with the service and final product. I respect their tradition and dedication to San Francisco but would never recommend they be used for a wedding
author: Calogero P.

description: We went to the new Victoria Bakery for the first time this week end.  They don't seem to have all the products they used to carry.  The young man with curly hair behind the counter was SO rude to me that I will never step foot in there again.
author: Rita R.

description:
One of my three favorite bakeries in the city (next only to Schubert's and Dianda's).  I grew up near this neighborhood, so their delicious cakes topped with gorgeous cream puffs were part of my childhood.  There were no other bakeries growing up.  Anyone remember when they made those cream puff swans?

This place has been here for years and I hope they stay around for many more years to come.  Every generation should be lucky enough to try their cream puffs.  Forget Beard Papa - this is the real thing.
We're getting a cake for a friend's birthday tomorrow, and you know I'm going to be first in line to get one.  OK, maybe the birthday boy will get the first one, but I'll be right behind him.
author: Denise M.

description:
Yelp usually does a great job at directing me to some quality restaurants and businesses, but unfortunately, it failed with Victoria Pastry Company.  After reading about the St. Honore cake, I thought to myself, "Well, that sounds like something tasty...let's order one for Dad's birthday!"  So having schlepped all the way over to North Beach to inspect the cake and put in my order, I was expecting quite a bit from it.  Too bad it didn't live up to expectations...

First off, I did not appreciate the fact that they got the inscription on the cake wrong.  All it needed to say was "Happy Birthday Papa" along with the date.  They got the first part, but didn't even bother putting in the date, which I specifically asked for.  This could have been caught at the bakery before I brought it home, but they had the box already tied up with string and I didn't want to seem like a bitch by asking them to undo everything.  That should have been a tip-off that something was wrong...all the other bakeries I've ever gone to, including the Chinese ones, show you the cake and the inscription before they box it up.  Its not a huge deal, but it would have been nice to get what I wanted on the cake.

The cake itself was just okay and not really worth the $27 I paid for an 8 inch cake.  The decorations on the cake were sloppily done- the little maraschino cherries were different sizes (honestly, would it have cost that much more to get full cherries, rather than quarter pieces?), the whipped cream turrets were uneven, and the whipped cream frosting on the outside of the cake didn't even fully cover the cake.  The cake looked more like something out of a home kitchen rather than a professional bakery.

As for the taste of the cake, I personally found that the taste of rum was a little overpowering.  The cake also seemed puny- there was only one actual layer of cake, while the rest consisted of a custard filling and some puff pastry at the bottom.  The only redeeming feature of the cake was the cream puffs, which were delicious.  I'm glad that they filled the cream puffs with custard, rather than the more standard whipped cream.  

The St. Honore cake from Victoria is unlikely to ever grace a birthday party in my family, especially since there are so many other bakeries to choose from.  However, I was intrigued enough by their cream puffs to want to venture back and try their cannoli, lemon bars, and other pastries.
author: Angela H.

description:
Service: 3.5/5
Food: 4/5
Wait: 4/5
Price: $
Presentation of food: 4.5/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3/5
Overall: 4/5

i had their sweet whipped cream filling chocolate pastry; it was crackinnnnn!
author: Eva H.

description:
The pastries are soooo good.  They are pretty expensive here...a canolli and hot tea for $7, but it's totally worth it once in a while.  The staff is not usually very friendly and today they were particularly obnoxious, talking bad about a co-worker really loudly.

If their food wasn't so good, I'd give them three stars, but I've had canolli, tiramisu, the cookies, and some cake and all were some of the best I've ever had.  For every now and then, this is a wonderful SF staple.
author: Amanda L.

description:
If you are strolling through North Beach and have a sweet craving, stop in at Victoria's and you won't be disappointed.  They make amazing cakes and sell individual slices of just about every specialty.  Love the cream puffs, cannoli, cookies.... and oohhh every person should try Victoria's St. Honore in their lifetime!

It's quite spacious with a good handful of tables so you can enjoy your sweets right on the spot -- it's a nice peaceful stop in the busy crossroads of North Beach & Chinatown.

And the service has always been top notch to boot --  friendly, cheerful, helpful. A true North Beach institution.
author: Cat K.

description:
FYI: Parking is horrible as you know just from the street (Stockton and Vallejo); the heart of North Beach. If you were to pick-up, I would suggest that you park at one of the parking lots on Stockton to your left for less than an hour its $2.50.

The Princess cake was sooo good, thats the cake with the green marzipan on top, its sooo moist! All the other cakes, tarts and pastries look sooo yummy! I would try the puff pastry cake, but its made out of rum, yuck! No thanks.
author: Karen F.

description:
Cannoli, how much do I love thee?  Let me count the ways.  

Victoria does one damn fine cannoli.  Creamy sweetened ricotta studded with mini chocolate chips in a crisp shell.  It would make my Sicilian grandfather proud.  On par with Veniero's in NYC.

I brought a boyfriend here once.  He had never sampled cannoli.  One bite and he was swooning.  It wasn't over me.

Bring your attitude and they may begrudgingly fill a shell up for you fresh if there aren't any in the case. 

Beware: The cannolis go fast on the weekends.
author: Liz P.

description: Gotta admit... I had my doubts, but that slice of Princess cake was amazing! I loved the soaked flavor of the cake. The marzipan, cream and raspberry filling was delicious. I don't usually like cake, mostly cause of the dryness. This one was very moist.
author: Vera W.

description:
OMG! Yes I said it and you'll be saying it to when you try the scone fresh from the oven and the flaky butter croissant.

I heard from reliable sources the cakes are AWESOME.  I am going to give it a try and I'll let you know how it turns out.
author: Po L.

description: I've come in and purchased a coffee cake and walked back to Bart and brought it back home to Danville in one piece to be enjoyed and savored by my family! There's nothing like a "real" bakery, the smell of all the wonderful pastries and cookies and cakes. So hard to choose, but I can only carry so much...probably a good thing!
author: Susan D.

description:
My coworker dragged me into the Victoria Pastry Company near Chinatown, after a long day's work and two hours of sleep the night before, claiming they have the best 'Eclairs in the world.

I took her word for it. 

1. I was still hungover.

2. I only had two hours of sleep.

3. WTF is an 'Eclair?!

Anyway, she bought me one and sure enough they were tasty, nearly orgasmic. Let's just say if I was 100 percent at the time of consumption, I would've bought a dozen of this fucking things and ate them all on the spot.

In retrospect, I'll just stick to eating my all-time favorite pastry from the liquor stores I used to frequent as a child in ghetto Long Beach:

Chocodiles.
author: Roel C.

description:
Credit where is due!  The pastries here are amazing, i gotta give it to them.  However, I am not sure the customer service has me eager to return.  Here is the story:  The first time i went, I was attended to by this little lady that was PISSED, she was slamming the counter doors and huffing and puffing and her face was red with anger when I wasn't sure as to what I was getting.  So, I was like "WTF!!?" and I asked her if there was a problem.  Well, she bit my head off, but at least she put her attitude in check and she was nicer to the next customer... and I was on my way home with a box full of delicious pastries.  Well, I was very much pleased with the product; but not so much with the customer service, particularly because it had been my first time there.  

Today while I was shopping in Chinatown for a cheap broom, I decided to stop by and give it another try.  The older-lady that helped me was very nice and helpful.  I left happy.  (Probably the only thing that I was not happy about was that the gorgeous boy that works behind the counter has not ever actually helped me.  I always get the girls.  Maybe one day I'll luck out!)  Well, I got home and I opened my box of pastries to find out that I was not given what I had asked for; I had requested a custard canollie, but instead I got an eclair.  It was delish anyway! 

 So, this is the thing that  gets me about San Francisco, there are tons of places with so much potential for being Gold-mines, given that their product is high in quality and value, BUT, the customer service is often weak.  I've found myself going to corporate businesses   mainly because there, the clerks' job description requires that they smile and treat me with respect.  SF's locally-owned businesses need to keep that in mind, if they wish to have us back as customers!  :)  

 Anyway, the pastries @ Victoria's are amazing!  They remind me of a pastry shop I used to go to in Boston on Hanover Street. :)
author: Inked I.

description:
Youra gooda boy....

Ok --- I am 37 and yet I didn't mind being called a good boy by the woman who concocted my tasty treats. You should know a couple things about me. I try really hard to eat well six days a week. The seventh is pure gluttony! And I plan for it. I strategize as to how I am going to indulge. Today it was Victoria Pastry Co. I made the family wait in the car as I ran in to order (mainly because I knew my wife's mouth would drop as I picked one item after another). "I'm gonna need a box" I said when she asked me what I would like.  I ordered 2 cannolis for myself, a piece of chocolate cake for my wife's belated birthday, a napoleon for me, a kitty cat cookie for my daughter, and a chocolate eclair for me. (I do think of others....) 

I consider my self a critique of the eclair; so questioned the contents, "is there real custard in there or something else" --- "I hava both custard and cream" = "Custard" I replied without hesitation. "And the napoleons too?" --- "Custard also" she retorted.
"one of those please"

"Youra gooda boy" she said and handed me a complementary piece of cinnamon sour cream cake ( not bad also). I could not wait to get home.

Now the review: the cannoli is as traditional as I have had in a while, not overstuffed with over-sweetened cream. The cookie was sturdy, and had more flavor than many of the other wafer types you find. The cream, though a bit bland for my taste, was very good. All in all, a solid A- for the treat. The napoleon: B+, though I am not a frequenter of the pastry. The pastry layers were a bit stiff, making the process a bit difficult to navigate. The custard was phenomenal! The cookie was good (and cute) and the chocolate espresso cake was very rich and moist; a clear A-. Now the best for last.

The best for last. Having tasted the custard with the napoleon, I could hardly wait to eat the eclair. But when I did, it surpassed my expectations. This is old school and what I mean by that, this is classic pat a choux, real custard and a fabulous chocolate ganache. This is like grandma used to make. The custard has been in the pat a choux just long enough for the texture to be firm on the outside and doughy on the inside. The ganache has a soft texture and melts on the roof of your mouth like a buttery kiss. A curve wrecker on the grading scale -  A+++.

I will be back --- next Saturday of course. As for the rest of today --- harris' steak dinner and crme brule for yet another desert. Then, back to the gym for six more days.

Added commentary:  Victoria vs. Beard Papa  - this is kinda like Mercedes versus Porsche --- the two are very distinctive and good. Victoria is old school and classic (Mercedes) where as Papa is more performance (Porsche). "It has an addictive chemical in it that makes ya crave it fortnightly smart ass" (bonus points to those you can source the quote, which shouldn't be too hard in this city). There is no clear winner between the two. Try them both --- I did --- and will, again, -
And again.
And.....
author: The Man M.

description: I have it on good authority that Victoria Pastry supplies Princess Cake to the Big Man in heaven.  And it never runs out either.  All you can eat Princess Cake.  That's why it is called HEAVEN!!!!
author: Caisa S.

description:
My head is turned.  But I am not skipping and hopping anytime soon.

I got what looked like a raspberry tart (w/ a gram cracker crust) that weight a ton & my greedy sissy got a cream horn.
The tart was good, but didn't take my breath away.  I left the other half for my sissy.  I can't say how the cream horn ranked cos it was all gone before I asked for a bite :( .  Must have been damn good.  

I'll only return if those dirt cheap / almost giving out for free Chinese bakeries are close (which they all seem closed after freaken 5!).  

Wait!  No I will return for cakes since everyone keep saying are 'stupid good' cake!   I am there baby!
author: MSee Y.

description: My friend and I were exhausted climbing up endless hills of SF. We were hypoglycemic and our hands were trembling. We walked into a random chinese dim sum place but walked out due to its questionable sanitary condition.  We were desperate for food. Then we saw Victoria Pastry Company and we knew we were saved. We bought a bunch and inhaled them in a matter of seconds. They were heavenly...
author: Jen K.

description: This place really brings back alot of memories. I still remember each year my mom would buy a cake from here for my birthday ^ ^ and they were goOod~! Thank you mommy ! lol So I was in the area the other day and decided to stopped by and ordered their Custurd Danish and their Cross Buns - A Cross Bun is Sweet bread with driend fruit and custard filling.Spring timeframe only! it was sooooo deelicious !!! me want more !! =D
author: Trina M.

description:
Their chocolate eclairs make the cream puffs at Beard Papa seem like quesionably-edible items your niece made from her easy-bake oven. Out of the kindness of your heart you take a bite, but dream of something much more savory and delicious. 

The sweets at Victoria Pastry is what you're dreaming of, whether you're aware of it or not.

Chocolate eclairs top my list, with whipped cream filling or custard. 

The location is best traveled via foot, as parking is a mess and it's on the corner of where Chinatown meets North Beach meets a bunch of crazy homeless people mulling about.
author: Kelly R.

description: Worst service I can remember.  Ruined a special day for a great group of people.  We will never return.  The staff should be ashamed.
author: Maxwell H.

description:
I wanted pies. She wanted cake.

Imagine: blueberry pies, key lime pies, apple pies -a cornucopia of pies!

How many times have you pie and thought  "Damn, this is good?"

And how many crummy wedding cakes have you eaten? My Auntie spent a small fortune on a cake from some fancy shmancy baker here in SF and I couldn't tell you if it was chocolate or vanilla.

Did anyone say "Damn, this is go-ood?"

If they go and see Victoria at Victoria's pastry, get the Princess cake with the marzipan frosting they sure as hell will. 

My wife and I went there two times tasting cake and found Victoria to be beyond polite and always generous with the tasting slices. Our cake was perfectly beautiful, delivered on time and easily assembled by the restaurant.

Many a gastronome were present, so I was nervous at the decision not to have pie. To my great satisfaction, the cake was enjoyed by a wide "palate" of preferences, from those accustomed to American style sugary sweets to a more Chinese style-both loved the cake.

Highly highly recommended.
author: Michael H.

description: This Italian bakery rivals those in NYC. Their napoleons are to die for -- and this coming from someone who doesn't care much for desserts. They also have some to die for rum balls! Situated on the edge of Chinatown and Little Italy
author: Anita L.

description:
This Bakery has been around forever and as they always say when a place is open for long, "there's a reason why"  

Well, unless it's one of those places that has been around forever and they have never ever have business.  Those are the fronts for the criminal families.  

This place could be still since it is an Italian bakery but even if it is, who cares, their cakes are great!  I've always went for their cream puff cakes and I really don't know if I've ever tried anything else.  

From generation to generation, this place is going to continually churn out some amazing cakes....  

My grandparents have eaten them, my parents have tried it, I continue to eat it and I know my future children will get a chance to try, try, try as well......
author: Mark W.

description:
Victoria gets 5 stars because it is head above the rest of the pastry/cake places in the city proper.  That I've visited so far.  Well, there was another great one that sold large individual slices of cake, but they closed over a year or two ago.  heh.

I'm of a mind that i do not have to love everysingle cake and cookie and pastry at a bakery/pastry place.  But there has to be enough to constantly lure me back.  Their cream puffs, eclairs, napoleons, st honore's, and cookies are absolutely delicious.  The cookies sold by weight ends up a bit expensive sometimes so i stick to the other items.  The only item I've tried that I found subpar was their tiramisu.  Otherwise, a consistant level of high quality delicious pastries and cakes!
author: Animal K.

description: Truly awesome cakes and cookies.  When I need to go all out and get a cake for a special occasion, this is the spot.  And it's not relegated to just Italian sweets--I got an absolutely killer Swedish Princess Cake there once.  It's also great for coffee and pastries.  I can't hang around this place too long as I'd put on 25 pounds just loitering.
author: Ralph B.

description:
Chocolate Eclairs are fattening.

Thanks a lot, Victoria Pastry.
author: Sachi T.

description: I enjoyed a deliciously rich slice of Princess Cake from this bakery when we celebrated a co-worker's birthday.  Soft, moist cake with a layer of custard, jam, and crushed almonds, and wrapped in sugary marzipan.  I've heard their other pastries are also worth the walk up to North Beach, and so I think I will be making the trek up during a lunch break if I'm ever craving pastry sweets.  The good thing is the walk up and down may burn off just enough calories to justify my eating sweets without special occasion!
author: Shar M.

description:
oh, strawberry shortcake, how does piggy love thee?

far too much, actually . . . which unfortunately tends to result in little piggies with stomachaches, as eating half of a strawberry shortcake in one day is wont to do .......

whoops, said the little piggy ( ' (oo) ' ) it was totally worth it though - especially as i ate the other half on day two (^(oo)^)v

red velvet cupcakes are tasty as well!
author: Vicki Y.

description: For years a cream puff cake from Victoria was the ultimate dessert reserved for only the most special occasions in our family.  Because this is not local for us, we would have to make a special trip out just to buy it.  We happened to be in the area the other day and decided to buy one just for the heck of it since we hadn't had it in a couple of years.  We were disappointed to find that they seem to be cutting back on the ingredients: the layer of chocolate was nearly indiscernible and the rum flavor was decidedly missing.  We may need to look elsewhere for that special cake.
author: M Y.

description:
Very good cannoli and bear claw.
Will have to go back to try some of their other options.
Only complaint, is that I would prefer if they filled the cannoli shell when you ordered like some places do in NY. It makes them stay crunchy for the walk home if you are taking it to go.
:)
author: Annie M.

description:
My parents bought a couple slices of cake/pastries from here a few days ago.  They've always told me that their cakes were pretty good.  They purchased:

1.   Zabaione Napoleon Slice
2.  Chocolate Custard Napoleon Slice
3.  (I don't remember the name of the cake, but it is not a napoleon.)

The napoleons seemed a little soft instead of crispy/flaky, so I would definitely go to Schubert's for their napoleon.  The cake was fluffy, but a little on the sweet side.
author: Yan M.

description:
yes, Yes, YES!  

This is the place to find fresh Cannolli's, a variety of little Italian cookies including Merengue, Macaroon, Biscotti, and several that I don't know what they are called. So, so delicious.  I stopped there for a cup of coffee,nothing fancy but good had a couple of biscotti to go with it and sat at a small table to enjoy the breakfast treat.  Since I was by myself, on vacation and not in a rush, I found myself making conversation with the folks at the adjoining table.  This is the kind of bakery that you will find local clientele hanging out in the morning having coffee, reading the paper and catching up on their day.  I absolutely loved it!  They have specialty occasion cakes and decorated gingerbread houses for the holiday season.  We bought several of the nougat candy that they make there to bring home for gifts.  

I give it five stars!  Wish we had a bakery like this where I live I'd be hangin' out in the morning too.
author: Susan K.

description:
The St. Honore cake is perfection.  They have alot of other goodies to
offer and believe me they're good but The St. Honore is an absolute
show stopper.  One of my all time favourite cakes.
author: M E.

description: Let me preface this review by explaining that I have been frequenting Victoria Pastry (other locations as well) since I was a young child, so least 20+ years. It has always been an absolute gem in my eyes, especially concerning their most prized and delicious princess cake. I have simply never tasted one as good...EVER. Needless to say, I went out of my way this past Sunday afternoon, traveling from the opposite end of the city for what should have been a very special treat. Boy was I shocked and dismayed by arguably the worst customer service I have perhaps ever experienced. Unfortunately I do not have the name of the server, but from the moment I walked in to order, the service my partner and I received was shockingly aggressive, ill mannered, and simply demeaning. When asked what we would like, I proceeded to order a napoleon and an almond torte. The first red flag occurred when the server proceeded to assertively rush me  as I was deciding what to order, and was extremely aggressive in his tone. He then proceeded to place my order into a box and while doing so, one side of the torte fell off--to which he used his bare hand to push back together. Unsanitary much?? From the moment after I stated my order, he loudly yapped the total price to me, ($9.10) probably a good six times. At this point he hadn't even finished wrapping my order, so I was confused at the veracity of his tone--especially being that there was no one else in line. By the seventh time he barked at me, I was really confused and quite perplexed. It was as if he thought I was going to run out of the establishment without paying? To make matters worse, he then shouted to my parter the price one last time, before my parter became heated and told him not to worry and that we were going to pay him. It was then that the server answered back that my partner was giving him a "weird look" so thats why he repeated the ten of $9.10 with sure a forceful tone. I have no idea what his problem was, but it made my parter and I feel so upset and uncomfortable, that we decided to walk out. It is moments like these that have the ability to make or break a business, regardless of the high quality of their product. I sadly and unfortunately cannot frequent this establishment again, especially this location. I am tempted to report this behavior to the labor board and /or health department, especially the grossly unsanitary portion of this experience.
author: Ahna K.

description: I run past here all the time on the way back for the gym, and finally gave in and grabbed a box since I was meeting up with a group of friends later in the day. Got a selection of pastries, the princess cake and some cookies, and I must say, the pastries were my favorite. Tried the apple filled which wasn't too sweet, and I didn't think I would like the blueberry and cream cheese pastry, but I had a couple bites and it was a pleasant surprise. I don't remember all the cookies that I got, but there was one with a hint of almond that had just the right amount of chewiness. The cookies are small so you can try a bunch of them without feeling TOO guilty, but be careful, because before you know it...you'll have eaten an entire bag. Princess cake was good, but a little to sweet and eggy for my taste. Cute place to spend a morning with a friend or even grab a pastry to-go to munch on in the park.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Wonderful bakery that has been here for years. 
Heaven on earth is their St. Honore cake and also 
their napoleons and tea cookies!
author: Minnie-Mousse' M.

description: I purchased a pecan pie to take to a thanksgiving dinner in San Mateo.  We all know that pecan pies are rich tasting.  I was extremely dissatisfied with the pie I bought.  It had absolutely no taste.............the pecans on top were good but I noticed that nobody at the dinner finished their slice.  I was very disappointed to say the least.
author: Marie A.

description:
I swoon at their almond cake - perfect with coffee - delectable napoleaon with whipped cream - meringue cookies and crusty rasberry bars -  everything so very dainty and ladylike and civilized - 

and it all comes in a bakery box tied with string.

Exactly on the border between Chinatown and North Beach - The fantastic Chinese Golden Gate bakery is only a block or two away - 

Did I say I Hella-Heart San Francisco yet?

Update:
Not to dis the Stella Pastry lovers, but I recently went to Stella instead of Victoria to compare their Napoleons and you know what?  Victoria Pastry's Napoleons (and total pastry selection) win for me.  So I stand by my original review.
author: Robyn C.

description: Yay! I found you...need to include a BOLD ANNOUNCEMENT next to the address to let old timers like me know this is a NEW LOCATION!!! I was deeply disappointed and saddened to see a new Chinese bakery now occupying your long time old spot on Vallejo and Stockton. Had I known you have moved, I would have trekked over to Filbert...now I know, but it took me some diligent search here on Yelp to figure it out. In any case, glad you haven't left us for good. Grew up with you and still buy your cakes for special occasions even after moving to the deep bowels of the suburb...
author: Lil D.

description:
No complaints. 

Their amaretti are amazing and authentic like what you'd get in piemonte.
author: Caroline C.

description: make a point of visiting here every time i'm in the city. great prices and great pastry!
author: Michelle R.

description: Wanting a dessert to take to my hotel for after dinner, I stopped in to check out their pastries.  The selection seemed low in late afternoon and, being a chocolate lover, I chose a slice of chocolate truffle cake.  Their machine for tying the strings around a to-go box was interesting to watch, and I was on my way.  The cake proved to be an excellent 'welcome home' after my Italian dinner out.
author: D. A.

description:
My grandma used to take me to an italian pastry shop like Victoria in so cal that had these sprinkle cookies that i was obsessed with...

After many many years of craving this sprinkle type cookie, I get taken to Victoria Pastry to try out the delectable  pastries and cookies they offer.. well guess what?? 

S P R I N K L E    C O O K I E    G A L O R ! ! ! ! 

OMG I was soooo EXCITED to see these cookies because no one ever makes them ANYWHERE...Right away I order nearly a pound of just sprinkle cookies.. I KNOW what a FATSO... =] WHO CARES, I have been deprived of them for way..... too long! FINALLY, my new pastry shop of choice!!!! SPRINKLE COOKIES once a month.. mmmmmm yummy!
author: Mai H.

description: Wow, the St Honore Cake!  Awesome!!  Work surprised me today with a baby shower and ordered the cake from here.  This cake is the best of both worlds, cream puffs and napolean flaky layers oh and delicious custard.  I'm telling you this hands down is the best cake ever, my baby is flip flopping from the joy as I type!  Thanks Victoria Pastry for this deliciousness!!
author: La C.

description:
I would have given Victoria's 5 stars for the delicious, consistent pastries I've had there. But the terrible service brings the overall rating down 2 stars. Maybe they count on the fact that their goodies keep customers coming back again and again. I've been buying Victoria's pastries since the '50s and moved out of the area in the '70s. I make it a point to get my Victoria-fix satisfied every time I visit The City. 

YUMMY! For special occasions, I've picked up a St. Honore cake ranging in size from 8" to a sheet cake. They are delicious with their layers of rum cream, cake, whipped cream (didn't it have a chocolate cream layer too?) and topped with delicious, light cream puffs. DElicious! The eclairs are just chocolaty enough and filled with fresh, sweet whipped cream. DElicious! I also have to get as many French cookies as I can to last me through to my next Victoria-fix. A French cookie is crunchy, buttery cookie on the bottom, topped with a sweet, almond-flavored piping of crunch in the shape of 2 D's back-to-back, with jams (peach and raspberry?) filling in the "holes." DElicious. 

SERVICE: Immature, negligent, and inattentive. Maybe they're relatives of the owners; they acted as if they really couldn't care less if there were customers there or not, whether the customers had questions or not, and 
whether those customers purchased anything or not.
author: G. Q.

description: The pignoli's were burnt and bitter.. the service was rude and disinterested.. I once loved this place on a previous trip now, not so much.
author: Alexander C.

description: We stopped in today for a quick treat. O.M.G. The best cannoli in the whole wide world. Better than any we had in Italy.  Hubby got the cannoli and I got a slice of chocolate raspberry cake. The cake was amazing. No need to chew; it simply melted in my mouth.  The shop was clean and the staff was very friendly.
author: Vickie P.

description: Love, love, love their cannoli's and almond torte. If ever I'm in the area, I will stop here to pick up a dessert.  I love it, not only because of how amazing desserts are, but it's historic and hasn't lost any of its charm. My mother-n-law grew up visiting Victoria's and introduced it to me (as her father did by his parents that immigrated from Sicily.)
author: M Y.

description:
I get hit with a huge wave of nostalgia whenever I think of Victoria's.

Grew up chowing down on their flakey, creamy, puffy St. Honore cake. We lovingly called it the 'ball ball cake' because fobs don't know how to say St. Honore...or really cared to for that matter. All we knew was the cake was the thing to look forward to on anyone's birthday. It was extra special if you got a slice with a whole puff AND a maraschino cherry...yum.

Now that picking up a cake here is totally out of the way, we don't get to enjoy it as often. sad face. BUT grandma's birthday is coming up, and I'm headed there later today so I can remind her of the good ol' days...and the ball balls she loves so much.
author: Chelle Y.

description:
I judge Italian bakeries by how good their pignoli cookies are... theirs was okay, bit too chewy and bit too sweet.. definitely not as good as stella's pignoli but okay. 

They look like they have a great selection of other pastries - will try next time...
author: Jim C.

description: Great coffee, but it bothers me that they don't carry soy milk. I've heard the pastries are incredible.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I was told several times that their cheese danish was "to die for."

I tried it finally, and while it was pretty good, i don't think it's "to die for"-quality. it's seemingly pretty ordinary. The crust was flakier than what I'm accustomed to with danishes, and the cheese was pretty good - nice and dense and not too sweet. all in all, it was solid cheese danish.

nevertheless, i don't think I'd really care to frequent this place. it's a bit far away from my office when I can just as easily go to Brioche (which also has a good danish, and better coffee). the selection of pastries seem pretty limited, though I'm curious how the others taste.

I think the real attraction of this place is its longevity. and I probably wouldn't go there on a daily basis, but it's something i'd get occasionally.
author: Bernie L.

description:
My husband and I rested here during our wandering around Chinatown. I was curious to see how it compares to Stella's a few streets over.
For me, it's not a good as Stella's...and my comparison is based on the cookies...the yummy very pricey cookies...especially the amaretto cookies covered with pine nuts.
For a cup of cappuccino and a couple small handful's of cookies, our tab as nearly $10.
It was nice to sit near the window and watch the crowds, and the Cantonese grannies and grandpas refreshing themselves inside with snacks and what I guess to be tea instead of coffee.
Now I can say I've been here, but I think Stella's will be my one and only place for buying over-priced Italian bakery cookies!
The young lady who came over to clean the table for a Chinese Grandma gets 10 stars from me. She was very gracious to an older lady who wasn't going to buy anything while resting for awhile inside. That was very good to see.
author: Lisa R.

description: Whenever I'm in charge of buying a cake for a celebration, I seize the opportunity to go to Victoria's and get their house specialty, the St. Honore cake.  The St. Honore cake is an incredibly indulgent treat that appeals to everyone with its combination of cake, custard, rum, whipped cream and cream puffs.  I bought a huge St. Honore cake for my coworker's shower and almost all of the 35 guests went for a second piece.  It's also very convenient to order cakes from Victoria's for parties since they deliver.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Let them eat cake! or even better Let them eat Italian cookies!

Love love love (little hearts are floating above my head) the absolute huge selection of Italian cookies and baked goods. I've found my inner Italian (although my Chinese side swears by honey almond cookies).  The biscotti plain or chocolate dipped were delicious and don't get me started on the amaretti pine nuts. Total bliss!  I thought the maraschino cherry butter cookies were a bit too sweet (Stella's does it bigger and slightly less sweeter).
For those who crave their caffeine in the morning rituals. They have a grand listing of lattes and espressos or whatever you grind heads desire.
I had the pleasure of doing a wedding cake tasting (you must make an appointment and you have to pay a small fee)...hands down their tiramisu was awesome!! It's not overwhelming, but just sweet enough for that kick you need.

Parking is not that great since it's borderline Little Italy and Chinatown...but if you've got mad luck skills, you might be able to squeeze onto street parking.  Better yet, go up Vallejo and park in the garages.
author: Pauline L.

description:
My family has been going to Victoria's Pastry since 1916.  The Rum Cake and the Saint Honore Cake are the best I have ever had. They are a regular for holidays and birthdays in our family even though we now live in the South Bay. The Zuccotto (a frozen sponge cake dessert with fillings) is a truly special treat. The cookies are just the thing to go with an espresso, coffee, tea, or a glass of milk.  The wedding cakes are as beautiful to look at as they are to eat.

The street parking is nonexistent most of the time. There is a parking  garage a block  or so away across from the Police Station so take a friend to circle the block while you run in to make your selections.
author: E G.

description:
Have enjoyed VP for several years now. A quiet place for a coffee, a sweet treat and reading the paper on a Saturday morning.

The shop does not cater to the impatient, foodie type, rather its for the person who enjoys the non-starbucks environment. I enjoy the people who run the place -- they recognize me and say good morning  -- and mean it! i feel good about supporting their business. 

most importantly, I've never had a bad treat, just last Saturday the apple turnover and coffee started my amazing weekend!  Never had a cake so can't offer any feedback there. Thanks for reading.
author: Nigel E. S.

description: came to the new home.  this bakery known for its st honore cake.  great location near my previous home, st peter and paul and washington square.  the items were delicious
author: Bill L.

description:
listen up fellas!!!!! the cannolis here are kind of slender and i'll tell you now, it's not about the length, it's about the GIRTH!!! 

with that said, their cannolis aren't overly sweet, which i like but the shell is a little too greasy for me. plus, charging $3.95 for something so small should be a crime!!!
author: Regina C.

description:
Homemade torrone. I thought I'd have to actually go back to Italy to find real torrone. 

You know those little nougat squares that come wrapped in cellophane, or in a little cardboard box with a woman's face on the front, that are hard as rocks and nearly break your molars? Well, there's also a soft version that is thick and chewy and studded with plenty of almonds AND hazelnuts. Victoria makes torrone fresh and serves it in big slabs.
author: Rosie R.

description:
Alright guys. SO i almost NEVER write reviews but I felt that i had to for this WONDERFUL place. 

Lets start the beginning of my journey.. 
We wanted to get cakes for Prom (4 full sheets) and were looking for a really good place and of course I go  on yelp, and TADAAAH. Victoria's Bakery popped right up with her famous princess cake (which are DELICIOUS btw). 

Anyways. So I go over there, and was very, very sad to find that it would cost 1500 for 4 full sheets (precut). But Victoria was extremely helpful and genuinely wanted to help and offered an alternative: mini napoleons, mini eclaires, and only 2 full sheets pre-cut princess cakes. She originally doesnt do mini cakes, but she said "for you, I do it." Dont you know thats the one thing a gir loves to hear?!~ It all came down to 1,100. A little bit over our budget... so she took 10 percent off and BAM. 990$ (barely matching our 1000 budget). WHOOOOHOOO!! 

To top it all off, she gave us a free saint honore cake, free slice of princess cake, and free cannoli. yummy. Great service, wonderful and cutesy lady (i love her accent tehe), and sure...the price might be a tad expensive, but its WORTH IT. Trust me!
author: Natasha S.

description: Home of cookies covered with powdered sugar goodness.
author: Jason B.

description: I got cookies and treats and a bunch of other things here, but how those turned out for me is completely irrelevant.  You come here for the Custard Napoleon my friends.  Yes, proper noun.  Treat him with respect, and he might let you live to tell your friends just how tasty he really is.
author: William B.

description:
did you know that there is a patron saint for bakers and pastry chefs?!
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Honor%C3%A9_Cake

and what better way to honor the french st. honore than with a decadent, creamy custard laden boozy cake topped with glorious CREAM PUFFS, perfected by victoria pastry. perhaps the peasants would have been more forgiving of marie antoinette if she had meant for them to eat THIS cake.

five stars just for the heavenly st. honore cake. amen.
author: Jen P.

description:
Since I was a child, the panettone bread, is the finest San Francisco has to offer.
The zucatto is awesome, the cannolis are very fresh , your grandmother would approve...
Hot cross buns when available ,can't be found any better, and the twice baked selection of italian cookies is the best.
Great cakes, make this a must for any good food journey...
Traditional hard working family business...
Update: For Christmas 2011, I ordered online some 2lb. panettone for the house and guests, it arrived quickly,baked perfectly...Still the best on the West Coast...
Update for Christmas 2012...
Just tried to order our Christmas panettone on line and their site is down due to their move.Really sad news that they are not  there any more,but hopefully the new location will be just as great, and that their site will be up soon.
Tradition on Grant  st.. has been changing for years,and  I cant imagine that corner without them or the ovens that were there forever.All the best to them from our family.
author: John W.

description:
Cappucino
Whip Cream Neopolitan
Chocolate custard filled eclair
$11.52
WTF??

Cappucino...never been to Italy so I can't say....it was OK I suppose.  Definetly did not blow my socks off.
Whip cream neopolitan...tasted like a pastry from Devon in the Chi. 
Chocolate custard eclair...whats the the big deal?  Did not blow my socks off. 

Had this meal been $7-$8 I would of felt the quality met the price, but for $11.52 you must be insane!

Even it is one of "the best old fashion pastry shops" in the US....just cause its old doesn't mean its good.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Enjoyed Victoria Pastry Co.- We attended the North Beach Festival and after tons of junk food, really wanted dessert. I remembered their location and we were excited to pick out a couple of things! Everything was pretty good. They seemed friendly and accommodating, and even though I didn't think it held up to some of the bakeries in Japantown (those people can bake pastries), we really enjoyed it, and would definitely go again, since it's in the neighborhood.

I just like a little more choices, which was my only argument... they didn't have quite the selection I would've hoped for... but we ordered two pastries and it was about $8 i think, which really? If you've shopped pastries much in SF, i think that's very reasonable... I've seen pastries go for $8 apiece! Would recommend.
author: Krista H.

description: Chocoate Eclairs & St. Honore cake - p e r i o d.  THE BEST!!!  FOR YEARS, THE BEST
author: Julie B.

description: The best eclairs and princess cakes in the city if you ask me. Not cheap though, but worth it for a special occasion. The service can be a little abrupt, especially if they are busy. Order ahead for the holidays, it's worth it.
author: Edward L.

description:
We bought a princess cake from this bakery and i have to say it was very delicious.I wasn't crazy about the green marzipan but the inside was just decadent. It was a white cake with whip cream and raspberry filling. YUM!!! If your little princess is a big or small. This cake will certainly bring a smile to her face. 

Try it!!
author: Denise C.

description:
this place has been around since forever. i've walked by here many a times and have had cakes from here and they've always been delicious. 

on my birthday i had a  craving for some princess cakes OMG it was  DELISH not too sweet, the cake was moist and the cream not too heavy. it's a rare that a cake has all three points spot on!! it's hard to find good  princess cakes and victoria pastry has one of the best i've tasted!!!:O)
author: Jo K.

description:
The princess cake alone is worth five stars.  It has a marzipan frosting, custard and berry sauce between layers of white cake.  On the day I was craving a slice, however, they would not cut slices from a cake that was sitting in the display case for a me and my friend.  No slices that day, they said!  I had walked miles and miles for princess cake!  I got no sympathy from the staff, but they did let me use the bathroom.  

Luckily Stella isn't far from there and has phenomenal slices of cake and delicious coffee drinks as well.
author: senna c.

description: I was sad to see Victoria's Pastry leave the location they've resided at for 100 yrs. but happy to see that they've moved closer to were I live! I love walking up the street for a special treat like a cannoli or an amazing piece of princess cake. Yum!  I have used them for special events like birthdays and even my wedding cake. The staff is great...very friendly.
author: J W.

description:
Love this place for the Cake that has the Cream Puffs around it !
Think it's fill with Custard ... 
It's very Yum Yum --- Delicious !
+ Very friendly staff
author: Roy L.

description:
I always loved the pastries at Stella's, so we went to their sister bakery, Victoria, for our wedding cake.

The cake itself was fine, but they recommended we get way more than we needed. We ended up with the whole bottom tier left over, most of which had to be thrown away. We wasted a lot of money. Strike one.

They refused to deliver it, even with over a month's notice to get someone on the schedule to bring it out--and we were willing to pay their outrageous $200 delivery fee. Strike two.

But the reason I was so upset was that they mis-decorated it. My mom went in with me and we told the woman taking the order over and over again that we wanted something just like in one of the pictures on their site, only with no roses. We told her maybe six times and she just nodded. Finally my mom asked her if she should write it down. We were having a Hawaiian themed wedding and wanted to put live hibiscus flowers on the cake. The roses wouldn't work with that. The woman said she'd remember and refused to write it down.

Of course, when the person who had so selflessly volunteered to go pick up the cake brought it in, roses on wires had been stuck in. I couldn't even remove them to re-decorate. I was already stressed out, so I couldn't help just busting into tears. The Victoria Pastry Company literally made me cry!

The cake was the one thing I really regretted about my wedding. Everything else was lovely, but we over paid, had to deal with incompetent and stubborn staff, and got a cake that just didn't look as good because it stuck out like a sort thumb.

I suppose we'll still go to Stella's for our annual Christmas cake, but the Victoria Pastry Company is out of the running. Forever.
author: Emy S.

description: Adorable Italian bakery! Such delicious treats... especially love their princess cake and torrone. An absolute must when in SF
author: Big E.

description: Love their almond macaroons and almond torte cake!
author: Karen M.

description: Delicious almond macaroons that are crisp on the outside, and soft on the inside. Yes, they cost like $5 for just 8 pieces, but it's a treat now and then. This place is a quaint neighborhood shop that's been family run for years.
author: Lina C.

description: Been coming here for a few ages and my bday cake was from here for several years. the St. Honoree. The one at Dianda's is exceptional, but the one from Victoria is actually my fav. When I'm in N. Beach, I usually stop off here or at Stella Bakery for a coffee and a Canolli. Its places like Victorias that remind me how blessed i am to live in such a wonderful city.
author: Adam X.

description: My sweets cravings sometimes go a little overboard and cause me to order too many pastries, which Victoria Pastry wouldn't call a bad thing, but my ass would. There are so many great sweets here that it might take you forever to decide what to get. I say splurge and get it all! The only thing I was really disappointed about was the quality of the pastries, they are good but not THAT good. They satisfy that something sweet craving for about 5 min. Definitely not as good as Miette or Citizen Cake's pastries, but good for the time being.
author: Sarah T.

description: I went to check out the new location for Victoria Pastry. I wanted to get a box of mixed cookies. The woman who waited on me acted like she could care less if I bought anything or not. It felt like I was inconveniencing her to ask her to do her job. I noticed that the selection of cakes was a lot smaller than at the old location. There were none of the traditional Italian cakes, like the almond tortes. There is one cake that my mom loves that I always liked to pick up for her. It was a standard cake that was always in stock before. I was told I now had to special order it, maybe two or three days in advance. Maybe they're trying to appeal to more American tastes. There were more chocolate layer cakes than I recall at the old place. Victoria was never known for having very friendly help in the bakery and that seems to have gotten worse since they moved. I think I'll be going to Stella from now on.
author: Mike m.

description: Pros: Very tasty and they have things that you can't find at every bakery. Cons: Service is only okay.
author: Tamara M.

description: Best Italian bakery in the bay area! I have never gone to North Beach without stopping here to get some cookies and connolis. My daughter's 1st cookie in her life was at Victoria's.
author: Michelle G.

description: In business since 1914, this neighborhood institution is one of the city's oldest bakeries. The shop is best known for its cakes - especially its signature creation, the St. Honore - extravagant layerings of liqueur-soaked sponge cake, whipped cream, and custard. If you're not in the market for a full-blown multi-tiered creation but still want to satisfy your sweet tooth, you can pick up a mini tiramisu, served snack-ready in its own to-go cup. As someone raised on Italian pastry in New York City, I find the selections here disappointing, as they're less varied and tend to be more French.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I went here to pick up cookies for a friend, and however i did not have anything but cookies and i have had better.  I will say that their christmas decorated cookies looked great and i have heard nothing but good things about their cakes.  There is a place around grant and green where i have only seen in the window but the cakes look spectacular!
author: Michelle M.

description: I have been going here since I was about 5 years old.  They have the most wonderful cannolis.  This past month was my Father's birthday and I wanted to get him a box full of cannolis instead of a cake.  I was in the south bay and about 2 hours out from the city.  I knew they would be out by the time I got there.  I called and they packed up a dozen for me and kept them cold until I got there.  Great service, delicious pastry and easy to get to.
author: Jenna B.

description:
My husband and I had a Victoria Pastry Princess Cake as our wedding cake (only with buttercream frosting instead of the marzapan so we could have it decorated the way that we wanted). It was very delicious!!!

When we came in for our tasting the lady who helped us was very nice and gave us generous portions to try. We came in with both sets of parents and she even gave each dad a big slice of the Princess Cake that they didn't have to share with any of the rest of us! :-) The moms, my husband and I all shared a piece, plus 3 other slices of other flavors that we were choosing between.

The wedding cake was beautiful and delicious. I would have given 5 stars if it weren't for two things:

1. We ordered a sheet cake in addition to the 3-tier wedding cake so we would have enough cake for everyone. The sheet cake was never delivered to the reception site and I didn't find that out until we were getting ready to cut the cake! Luckily we didn't end up needing it. There was enough cake for everyone who wanted it (plus a little extra - we got to keep the top tier). The owner was very nice about reimbursing us for the $ that we spent on the sheet cake that we never received

2. At our tasting I brought the dimensions of our Lenox cake topper because I wanted to make sure that it would fit. The lady did not write down the dimensions and insisted that the cake topper would fit. Well...on wedding day it did not fit. The cake still looked pretty with fresh flowers that my mom collected from the guest book table as our cake topper (good thing she entered the ballroom before any of our guests did to check it out). Nobody knew the difference and the beautiful Lenox cake topper was still part of our wedding day as it sat on the cake table beside the cake.
author: Lisa Z.

description: I got the AMARETTO cookies here bc I didn't see any rainbow cookies here :( They were good, but a little too soft. They also cost a whopping $17 per lb. That's way more expensive than some of the best in NYC.
author: Laurie c.

description: it's sugar lover's paradise..but i'm not a sugar lover...but....i'll take a sliver or a bite...their cream puffs (custard) is delicious....the cream puff rum cake is fabulous....the princess cake is a work of art and sculpted to perfection....
author: Hen A.

description: It gets most of the points for kitsch, since everything I've had here has been just okay. I've tried desperately to fit in with the cool crowd and love this place, but I don't really. The chocolate chip cookies are large but taste disturbingly like drywall. Maybe the cakes are better. I'd rather just look around the shop than eat anything, though.
author: Megan W.

description: I picked up a birthday cake for my mom here and she loved it. Now that's a sign of a good cake as she rarely eats sweets. I don't think I can ever go back to supermarket cakes, no matter now convenient they are.
author: Nathalie L.

description: Ohhhh their saint honoré is just beyond decadent! Everything else is good, but I usually only come here for theit saint honoré...
author: Maddy S.

description: All the pastries are top notch, but the cakes and almond torts are truly the best at this bakery. Any of the almond cookies are also worth a try, and if you want a sample of a cookie, just ask. They're really nice about that kind of thing here. The cannoli are the best in North Beach, by far.
author: Gabriela O.

description: Tradition is a beautiful thing. We get this Saint Honoray cake for mom every year ands the smile onher face is everything, its a must Saint Hororay cake yesss, Yummmyy, Cream puffs, cake and more cream and custard
author: P C.

description: The Amaretti Pignoli (pinenuts) are the best! These cookies are just the right combination of crunchy on the outside and chewy on the insidel....nothing else like it! Another favorite is their St. Honore cake. This place is a North Beach institution since 1914 when 2 Sicilian brothers opened it using a huge brick oven. A must when you are in the neighborhood.
author: Arlene C.

description: What does it say about me, a 35 year old Samoan man, 6 feet, over 200 lbs and looks like he could play defense for the 49ers walking into Victoria's Pastry and ordering a slice of the Princess Cake?  Gay?  Yeah.  You'd guess right.  Into the most delicious cake that I'd gladly sell my mother for?  Oh...MOST definitely!!
author: Gordon A.

description: This place is awesome for old fashioned unfussy cakes and cookies. I had some pignoli cookies here that were AMAZING. I recommend that you try what you're unaccustomed to here because they kept pleasantly surprising me.
author: Jane K.

description: Major rival to Stella, hard to say which is better. The canolis are great and so are the pine nut cookies. My favorite window display they did a year or so ago back was in honor of Big Love. It was a wedding cake with the usual bride and groom on top, but it also had an additional bride and a little Big Love logo...
author: Nicolas H.

description: As a kid, we used to get a lot of cakes here and I think after a while of trying different things, my parents got tired of this place and started going to others. This place really has mediocre desserts. There is absolutely nothing special about this place. If you happen to be there then I say go in and buy something to try but definitely do not go out of your way to buy your desserts here. Schubert's, Dianda's and the Tiramisu at Stella's are so much better. This place really cannot compete.
author: Diane M.

description: When I was little we would fly down to visit my grandfather on Nob Hill and we would go to local eateries and places like this remind me of those day, the old SF that was slightly less shiny and new and much more neighborhood-centric.  I love this place and always stop for some tea and a pastry when I visit.   Victoria's is wood paneled with cafeteria type tables and a huge glass case filled with colorful delights that the kids will love.  I love the quiet neighborhood and their pastries are very good for a mom and pop place.  Victoria's is old SF and it's been there for eons.
author: april d.

description: I get my birthday cake here every year. They have ruined Princess Cake from anywhere else for me. The new girl with the short hair is really nice, otherwise the service is apathetic at best. I've tried a couple of their other pastries but was not impressed. The Napoleon tasted a bit soggy but really, the Princess cake makes up for it completly. Also once I ordered one with chocolate cake instead of vanilla and it was DIVINE.
author: Nadia P.

description: I have no clue why I have never tried Victoria's, especially since I have always heard that it one of SF's finest.  So, I was in the city and decided to trug through a section of Chinatown in the hopes that the bakery lives up to my high expectations.  Once inside the crowded bakery, we decided to get a slice of Princess Cake and a small red velvet cupcake.  The Princess Cake was to die for- the cake was moist and the marzipan frosting was sweet.  The red velvet cupcake was just okay because both the frosting and cake were a little dull.  Overall, Victoria's is one of San Francisco's finest, and I will be back for their sweet treats.
author: Shannon W.

description: Love their St Honre cake, sooooooo GOOD!  I was introduced to this cake by a coworker, after that, I was craving it for almost ayear. I just got a 6" this last Saturday!  My husband tried their Tiramisu as well, he said it was really good as well.  I do have to agree they are a bit pricey, but every now and then I think its a good splurge!
author: Trina C.

description: I enjoyed the cream puff and the street view from the cafe; but I wish they would clean the display cases.  A dingy display is pretty unappetizing to me.  The photos on yelp from other customers are encouraging.  I will most definitely return and work my way from one end of the counter to the other!
author: Frankie G.

description: Try the raspberry twists and the gelato in the freezer is amazing, especially Hazelnut when they have it.
author: Meredith G.

description: REALLY good croissants.  Not chocolate ones, the plain ones.  I have not tried anything else here but the croissants.  They are flaky on the outside and soft and pillowy on the inside.  I have come here numerous times, and they are consistently good.
author: Sarah F.

description: This place did my wedding cake. 4 Stars because it tasted amazing. BUT...not the greatest customer service, prices aren't posted anywhere, and she didn't quite make it to my exact specifications. But the price was low enough for me to be really happy with the choice.
author: Anna G.

description: Victoria Pastry since 1914! They must be doing something right. I'm a fan of their croissants; they're perfectly flakey and airy. I especially like how they do their almond croissants, no filling just a glaze of sliced almonds on the top and complimented with a dusting of powdered sugar. They also have an assortment of pastries, cakes, and Italian cookies to choose from. But I do want to complain about my coffee during my last visit. I don't know if it was burnt or what was wrong with it but it tasted so bad that i couldn't finish it. But when you have good pastries/cakes it's allowed...I guess.
author: Doris Y.

description: Yummy bakery in china town. Try the cheese danish and blueberry cream cheese pastry. It's super goo!
author: V N.

description: they made a friend's birthday cake and it looked beautiful, I assumed it had fondant as thats what it looked like on top and was kind of dreading eating the stuff (fondant doesn't have the best taste) but when tasting I realized it was a lovely marzipan, which Im also not a huge fan of but it was just the right thickness and texture. The cake was moist and wonderful with two layers of whipped cream and some sort of raspberry filling. I will definitely have to get my next cake from Victoria's
author: Meg L.

description: I love their princess cake with the moist cake, smooth cream and almond paste.  Yum ... princess cake!
author: Sara A.

description: the princess cake, pastry's and the coffee are great... i come in almost every morning before work, every pastry that they have has been in my stomach mmmm...??? maybe 3 times lolz... they do a great job for years and years... Get there early though cuz they sell out quick, it's a great hangout spot between little ltaly and chinatown...
author: jonathan h.

description: I LOVE THEIR PRINCESS CAKE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! YUm! =) and I remembered trying a few other cakes here before as well.. I never had any complaints. love this place
author: A L.

description: I didn't really like this place but their service is excellent. Their food has this kinda "shop taste" to it. Basically, you can taste the store in its food. But I like their Halloween cupcakes and their holiday cookies are very unique. I should come here again to maybe check it out!
author: Vivian L.

description: The St. Honoré Cake is brilliant, better than any other cake I've had.  Their Princess Cake is also fantastic, although I have to admit that when I originally ordered it, it was meant as a joke because of the colour and it turned out to be an amazing hit.  Can not believe that I have yet to try the tiramisu.  All that said, I have not set foot inside of the SF shop.  For 15 years I have ordered cakes for special occasions and have always had the best results!
author: Susan M.

description: My hubby loves its chocolate cake.  It's very rich, creamy and very "chocolate" but not bitter.  Although the price of the cake there is expensive, I won't hesitate to indulge my hubby some time.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Over the top fancy cakes and good baked treats.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Tollhouse chocolate chip cookies...I ate a half pound of them on my walk back home.  Yum.
author: Mark D.

description: YUM. I love the "feet of the dead" or whatever cool name they give you for their macaroons with nut assortment.
author: Andrew W.

description:
ive been to victoria bakery several times due to the fact that my friend works there. the people that work there (including my friend) are really friendly. i like their pastries better than their cookies. their pumpkin muffin is soooo good. i like their cookies, but ive had better. i like their pinenut cookies, their the best. anyways its a pretty good bakery. i must admit ive never tried their cakes, but im picking one up for my dad's b-day!




new note: found out a lot of their shit is old....... im thinking of not going here anymore......
author: bridge A.

description: Their pine nut amaretti are indeed quite delicious. I had to wait a really long time to buy them though, I think because it was before Christmas. This woman in front of me ordered a cake and she was annoyed because they jacked up their prices for the Christmas season and charged her $2.00 to write "Merry Christmas" on top of the cake in red frosting. Well the pine nut amaretti was good, oh and this really really good looking guy works thereeeeee at least back in December ;)
author: O K.

description:
i am only rating on their princess cake. 

this cake is soooooo unbelievably delicious. if you're ever in a situation where you want to impress, make sure to pick up one of these bad boys... you won't be sorry. 

ladies, this cake is PERFECT for a baby shower.
author: eve l.

description: You all rave about the St. Honore cake, and I did as well, once upon a time. Perhaps I should try it again, but my last recollection (on my birthday) was that the cake was predominantly whipped cream, and hugely disappointing. Perhaps it was an off day, but you do go in expecting perfection...
author: Leah B.

description: The cookies taste as if they're made with shortening instead of butter.  Some of the desserts don't look that bad, but there are so many better places in San Francisco, skip this place.
author: Emma Q.

description: I got the princess cake as my wedding cake here, or actually from the one in Marin, but it was the best freakin cake Ive ever had!
author: kelley d.

description:
Wow what a total disappointment! I trolled Yelp reviews looking for a place to get a birthday cake for my daughter's 5th birthday. After reading so many positive reviews I decided on Victoria. I also like the fact that it seemed like a neighborhood favorite and local mom & pop place. I called first to make sure that doing a kids b-day cake was something they could do and the lady said sure come on down to order it.

So I troop down with my four year old and baby, find parking in Chinatown and the lady behind the counter is a total nightmare! A young girl was trying to help me but she needed to consult with I'm guessing was the owner, an older lady, and that is when things went downhill. She was so completely rude that I was caught off guard. I could tell that the younger lady was really embarrassed because she kept apologizing. The older lady was downright nasty when all I was trying to do was order a pretty basic cake, have them decorate it for a kid and add a candle that I brought along.

If you don't want to do a kids cake fine, I understand that it may not be their thing but don't tell me you can on the phone. And above all lose the attitude. What a total waste of time.
author: Brooke M.

description: I am giving this place one star because of the awful service I got today. The girl with black hair and bad eye make up behind the counter was rude and she acted like she was doing me a favor by serving me. Absolutely unprofessional. I used to like coming here because of the old Italian woman behind the counter and the friendly neighborhood service, but I won't be coming back.  There are other places around the I can go to like Caffe Triste or Stella Cafe & Pastry.
author: A M G.

description: Two words - princess cake!  Be ready to indulge your taste buds.
author: John c.

description: I love this bakery and pastry shop. Their brioche, eclairs and napoleons are delicious. They also do tasty cakes and cookies. I can never go to north beach without picking something up from here. Take a number!
author: chip n. c.

description:
after driving aimlessly around the city, i was cravin some darn sweets, and thank god for internet connection on my fone... lol. =)

the lady in the front was so cute.. every other word, "dear this, dear that."

lady: "what do you want, dear?" 
me: points to a certain pastry "that one please." 
lady: "is that all you want dear?"
me:  "yes please." 
lady: "anything else dear?" 
me: "no thank you" 
lady: "that will be $2.xx, dear."
me: "thank you." 
lady: wraps my pastry in a bag and hands me over my pastry... "here you go dear." 
me: "thank you.." 
lady: "have a great day dear."  =)

they should seriously reconsider REnaming their place to "Victoria DEARest Pastry Company" 

i have YET to try their cakes since most of the yelpers are yelpin about how faboulous their cakes are ... 

BUT, 

i did in fact, come in here  to buy me some breakfast pastries for the following morning, but lo and behold, i ended scarvin down my breakfast pastry, (i should have bought more than one, but there's so much to pick and choose in the city of sf, i'm just going to take one nibble at a time) on the way back to sonoma because it was pretty darn good... 

i believe i got the blueberry and cheese...

it was like.. how do i describe this? love at first taste? hm... idk. but the sweetness was pickin my teeth/mouth FO SHO! rawr!

crap. now, what do i eat for breakfast other than me eatin simply cereal and/or an egg muffin w/ham and cheese..

if parking wasn't so bad, and if there wasn't all these crazy one way streets, oh and random people wandering in the streets like mad ants, i think i'd stop by again...
author: Jennifer S.

description: i came. i tried. i liked. i'll be back. great bakery. pretty cakes.
author: Michelle I.

description: I grew up 2 blocks from Victoria's. Their Italian pastries are delicious and to die for. The St. Honore Cake with the cream puffs are the bomb. The place has since changed owners I'm sure, since the little Italian ladies have been replaced with little Chinese ladies.. They are smack dab in the middle of Chinatown!
author: RED L.

description: Got our wedding cake here and have been getting birthday cakes for 7 years.  Love them!  Reasonable prices too
author: Virginia C.

description: Love the polentina cakes and the marzipan pastries and pink string-tied boxes.  The counter staff, not so much.
author: e g.

description: my cannoli quest brought me to victoria today. after being disappointed with stella's last week, victoria was a welcome breath of fresh pastry. their cannoli is really deep-fried perfectly. the dough is not too thick or too thin. the amount of powdered sugar and ricotta cheese is just perfect so that the cannoli itself is not sweet to the point where the dessert is no longer delectable. there were plenty of chocolate chips and two maraschino cherries adorning the ends of the cannoli. at 3.95, this is what i expect, although it was a bit smaller than i expected. a great cannoli altogether, and the woman who helped me was very kind as well. the only thing that didn't work so well for me was the fact that the cherries had no flavor whatsoever. they might as well not have been there. i'm guessing they probably were not fresh. the best cannoli i've had still hails from nora's patisserie in colma, but this came in a close second.
author: Danny C.

description: Because I live in the neighborhood, stopped for quick sweets and ended up with chalky old pastry.  Also had some cake for a party, but not impressed with the quality.  I would rather go Stella in North Beach.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: truly disappointing, please pass this onto the owners ... besides screwing up the order, the cake was void of flavor ... the low price should have been a tipoff ... i should have bought a slice first!  lesson learned, sweet stop is usually my go to, but being so close to my workplace, oh regret ... next time; yelp for help!
author: tim y.

description: Hands down best custard eclair in town. Good assortment of cookies as well.
author: Alisa R.

description: Went there this last weekend for some tasty pastries in the North Beach area of SF.  The place looked good inside, but the pastries were less than good.  The person that helped us was rude and rolled her eyes.  We asked about nuts in some of the pastries, because some of us are allergic.  We still wanted to give the place a shot.  We took the pastries home to enjoy  later in the day and found that 2 of them were burnt on the bottom and dry inside.  After discovering this, I called to notify them.  They took down the info and said that a manager would call us the next day.  The manager did not call us back and we had to call again.  Speaking to the manager, she said that she would not refund our money and hung up on us.  We called back to find out why and she hung up on us again.  This is very poor customer service and the manger acted very childish.  I would not recommend this place to anyone.  I have never been treated like this from a business before.
author: Alan A.

description: We had heard about this pastry shop a lot. So a few days ago, for my birthday, my husband suggested that we buy a cake from Victoria Pastry. So we crossed town and it took us for ever to find parking and then, after a long wait, we got a chocolate cake that looked great. But when we got home and tried it it was totally stale. and it wasn't jut a little stale, it was at least one week old, or probably more. I stopped after one bite. None of our guests could eat it either. I am surprised that it actually didn't get us sick. The next day I called them and complained, but an empoyee answered and just took my name and number and they never called back. I didn't want to cross town again in order to return it. But that stale cake cost $20 and I will never go there again.
author: farinaz A.

description: This place is pretty good BUT REALLY PRICEY. I love their cookies and their chocolate croissants.
author: Miss D.

description: Not my taste of bread, too soft. Very typical Chinese style of western bread, like those stuff I had in mainland China.
author: Virginia T.

description: After lunch at The Stinking Rose (see my revie,) my cousin and I decided to venture to Victoria.  Having had pastries from them before, I can say they are among the best.  The taramisu is light, yet complex with lady fingers, savery marscipone, and chocolate.  The conoli is crispy with savery marscipone, dark chocolate shavings, and a fresh cherry.  The custard eclare is to die for with custard so thick that it holds the pastry together, as opposed to it comming apart.  The custard is thick yet light; the pastry itself is light with a wonderfully thin chocolate on top.  Round it off with a decaf or regular coffee which is just right and you will not be disappointed.  So, for excellent Italian pastries at reasonable prices with friendly service, Victoria Pastry cannot be gbeat.  The shop is clean with plenty of tables to sit and mingle at while looking out on to busy North Beach.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.
